metadata.case_name: Accused Nos. 1 to 10 and 12 v. State of Gujarat

facts.text: In the village of Aithor there are about 300 houses of Kadva Patidars and about 15 to 20 houses of Leva Patidars.

On January 16, 1961, at about 8 P.m. seven persons, who are Leva Patidars, came to the chowk where there is a pan shop cabin of Girdhar Shanker. These seven persons were, Rama Bhupta, Lakha Madha, Hira Punja, Jetha Nagar, Parshottam Prabhuva, Manor Madha and Gova Shiva.

At the same-time the 12 accused also came to that place. Accused 1 to 6 were each armed with a muzzle loading gun accused 7, 8, 11 and 12 were armed with sticks accused 9 and 10 were armed with dharias.
Accused 1 to 4 fired their guns and Rama Bhupta fell down and died near the door of the cabin of Girdhar.
Accused 5 and 6 fired their guns and Lakha Madha was injured.
Accused 1 fired his gun again and Jetha Nagar received injuries.
Accused 5 and 6 fired again and Hira Punja was injured.
Accused 7 to 12 were inciting accused 1 to 6 to kill all these persons. Other specific acts were attributed to some of the accused.

The learned Sessions Judge held that Rama Bhupta was killed as a result of the firing by accused 1 to 4, that Lakha Madha was injured by the firing by accused 5 and 6, that Jetha Nagar was injured by the firing by accused 1, that Hira Punja was injured by the firing by accused 5 and 6, that accused 12 caused stick injuries to Lakha and that accused 8 caused injury on the tongue of Parshottam Prabhuva.
The Sessions Judge also held that the 12 accused constituted an unlawful assembly, but their common intention was not to kill Rama Bhupta but only Madha who was present in the chowk.

Sessions Judge acquitted all the accused under S. 302, read with S. 149, of the Indian Penal Code, but convicted accused 1 to 4 under s. 302, read with S. 34, of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced them to imprisonment for life and to a fine of Rs. 2,000 each; convicted all the accused under s. 324, read with S. 149; convicted accused 5 to 12 under S. 326, read with S. 34, and s. 324, read with s. 149 and s. 148, of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to various periods of imprisonment and fine.

The accused preferred different appeals against their convictions and sentences and the State of Gujarat filed appeals against the acquittal of accused 5 to 12 under S. 302, read with s. 149; State filed criminal revision for enhancing sentences, but did not file appeal against acquittal of accused 1 to 4 under 302/149.

The High Court convicted accused 1 to 4 under s. 302, read with ss. 301 and 34, and confirmed life imprisonment but set aside fine; convicted accused 5 to 12 under s. 302/301/34 and 302/149, sentenced all to life imprisonment.

The High Court found that the common intention of the accused was to kill Madha, that accused 1 to 4 shot at Rama mistaking him for Madha, as Rama had dressed himself in the habiliments similar to those in which Madha used to dress himself.

It is common case that if the conviction of accused 1 to 4 under s. 302, read with s. 34 and s. 301, was set aside, all accused acquitted on major offences; if confirmed, appeal of other accused fails.

legal_issues.text: Whether the conviction of accused 1 to 4 under s. 302, read with ss. 34 and 301, of the Indian Penal Code, was correct, given common intention to kill Madha but Rama killed under mistake of identity.

petitioner_arguments.text: Accused 1 to 4 could not be convicted under s. 302/34 as there was no common intention to kill Rama, but Rama was killed under the mistake that he was Madha. A mistake by one or other of the accused cannot possibly be in furtherance of the common intention.
Provisions of s. 301 IPC cannot be invoked in the circumstances of the case.

court_reasoning.text: Section 34 IPC: When a criminal act is done by several persons, in furtherance of the common intention of all, each is liable as if done by him alone. Criminal act is united criminal behaviour resulting in punishable offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Common intention implies pre-arranged plan; inferred from conduct.

court_reasoning.text: To invoke s.34, criminal act done in furtherance of common intention; 'furtherance' means advancement or promotion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Shooting sentry or wrong person or twin brother under mistake is in furtherance of common intention to kill intended victim.

court_reasoning.text: Killing Rama under mistaken identity (believing him Madha) is criminal act in furtherance of common intention to kill Madha; accused 1-4 shot at him believing he was Madha.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mistake itself not part of intention, but act done in furtherance.

court_reasoning.text: S.301 IPC (transfer of malice) not applicable: deals with situation where death neither intended nor known likely for victim killed; here, accused shot particular person intending to kill him though mistaken identity; ingredients of ss.299/300 satisfied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Aid of s.301 not called for.

holdings.text: All the accused are liable under s. 302, read with s. 34, of the Indian Penal Code.

precedents_cited.relevance: Defined 'criminal act' in s.34 as united criminal behaviour resulting in punishable offence.
Conditions for s.34: criminal act by one in furtherance of common intention of all; implies pre-arranged plan.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: S.34 for common intention liability; s.301 transfer of malice not applicable; convictions under 302/34, etc.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; convictions of all accused under s.302 read with s.34 (and for others also s.301/149 as per High Court) confirmed; all sentenced to life imprisonment.

key_quotes.text: "If the common intention was to kill A and if one of the accused kills B to wreak out his private vengeance, it cannot possibly be in furtherance of the common intention... But if he kills B bona fide believing that he is A, we do not see any incongruity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes private act from mistaken act in furtherance of common intention.

key_quotes.text: "The shooting of the wrong man is in furtherance of the common intention and so S. 34 applies."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Illustration clarifying application of s.34 to mistaken identity.

key_quotes.text: "We, therefore, hold that without the aid of s. 301... it can be held that when accused 1 to 4 shot at Rama they shot at him in furtherance of their common intention to kill Madha."
key_quotes.speaker: court
